title: Manchester United Supporters Trust slam club for showing 'zero commitment to training staff'
text:
John Whale suffered fatal head injuries when he fell down stairs as he left a Manchester derby in 2017

Manchester United have been accused of showing 'zero commitment to employing and training appropriate staff' in the wake of the death of an 80-year-old supporter.

As revealed by Sportsmail, John Whale suffered fatal head injuries when he plunged down steps inside Old Trafford as he made his way out after a Manchester derby.

The club were slammed by a coroner after a three-day inquest at which a jury found that the behaviour of two blundering stewards had directly contributed to the pensioner's tragic end.

The vice chair of the Manchester United Supporters' Trust voiced his frustration about the incident on Thursday night.

Ian Stirling said: 'We know what the issue is. Zero commitment from the club to employing and training appropriate staff.' Stirling also claimed that United, who last month announced record revenue, were doing things on the cheap.

'It's price-driven,' he added. 'Stick them on minimum wage and accept a high turnover of staff. How can anyone show such a lack of care for an 80-year-old supporter?'

Stirling called on United to listen to fans, who have been raising concerns over stewarding at Old Trafford for some time. 'They need to stop seeing supporters as a problem and take our views seriously,' he added.

Meanwhile, it is understood that local MP Kate Green will be raising her concerns over the tragedy in Parliament.

authors: Ian Herbert For The Daily Mail
